title: How to differentiate between criticism and constructive criticism - Quora

response.answer_text: Criticism aims to tear you down, constructive criticism aims to tear your work down— figuratively of course. By that I mean that criticism is a personal attack, “you are stupid” “you should never write/whatever again” Constructive criticism aims to make your work better by telling you what’s wrong with it “this would be more realistic if xyz happened because blah blah facts” “I think it’d be better if you used the word ‘frustrated’ rather than ‘seethed with annoyance’” Constructive criticism can range from harsh “this is the worst thing I’ve ever read and here’s why:” to gentle “I suggest xyz, or maybe you could x?” It doesn’t always feel good, but it isn’t meant to hurt you, they are simply giving you feedback. To get the most out of constructive criticism, it’s important not to conflate the thing you have created with yourself/self worth. The sooner you listen to what they’re saying the quicker you’ll get better, so long as you are careful to distinguish between a criticism of skill or a criticism based in preference(you don’t have to write something a certain way just because that’s the way they want it). Put another way, one passes judgement on the creator and the other passes judgment on the work.

In this context, I believe criticism only tears down, while constructive feedback (constructive criticism) is given with the intention of helping the other person to improve. Constructive feedback doesn’t stink of judging, and will offer suggestions to improve. I once had a press release come back with one note written on it: “Not good.” This was the most useless feedback I’ve ever received, and it was from a guy who’d never actually seen a real press release before (and I have no idea why he was involved in the review cycle, lol). Now, that was real criticism. Haha. The CEO, fortunately, had constructive feedback: “We need to revise this to focus on this other product feature, as it’s what differentiates our product.” I hadn’t been told that by the account lead, and in learning that, I was able to rewrite it in a way that met their needs. Whether the creation is fiction or a marketing piece, the difference is the same. Telling you “I hate this character” doesn’t help you at all, and is rather judgmental. Telling you “I found this character unsympathetic, and so the Inciting Incident in your story didn’t draw me in” is maybe not great, but it’s a whole lot better because it doesn’t judge, and states it in such a way that you could figure out at least what problem I had with it, and maybe do something about it. If I also suggested a plot point change that would make the character more sympathetic, as a reader, that would help even more. Hope that helps in some way, lol.
